doc.field: The Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
Monroe Hill: Law office in center
creation: 1788; alteration: 1790; alteration: 1814; alteration: 1848; alteration: late 19th century; alteration: 1929-1930

Thomas K. Fitzpatrick, Head of School of Architecture, Home circa 1967--William M Thornton Home 1887-1935--Thomas Randolph Price Home 1882-1887--Charles Scott Venable 1865-1876--Maj Edmund Broadus Home 1846-50--UVA Proctor Arthur S Brockenbrough Home, early 19th century--Capt John M Perry Home 1814-1817--John Nicholas Home 1805-1814--James Monroe Home 1790-1799--Main house east part probably built first as a 1 story hall-parlor. Had a Flemish Bond outbuilding to the northeast of the main house which was later incorporated into the expanded 2 story, 2 pile brick main house.--Lower Plantation

Originally 1 Story Brick, 1 Cell, wood Shingles, then 2 Story Brick, 2 Pile, Paired Column Portico, Hipped Roof, 5 Bay (not symmetrical), 2 Pile, Flemish Bond, 3 Course American Bond, 5 Course American Bond, Winter Kitchen, Transom with sidelights with Italianate door, 6 Panel Doors, 4 Panel Doors, 9/9, Splayed Window Openings, Blinds, Brick Arcades with Brick Dentil Cornice, Law Office, 12 Dormitories, 5 Course American Bond Brick Outbuilding, Had 1 Story Frame Kitchen with Brick Nogging, 20'x28'
John M Perry, builder 1814--George Sidney Ford, remodeling late 19th century
survey data: Charlottesville's Historic Landmarks Study Surveys--Studies in Vernacular Architecture--Virginia Road Traces%Mutual Assurance Society Insurance Policy
James Monroe acquires property--Law Office--Arcaded 12 Dorms Added
